Benthic Habitat Suitability Card: This report displays overlap with benthic habitat suitability maps for macrobenthos communities found in the Belgian Part of the North Sea.
Benthic Habitat Suitability Card - learn:
ℹ️ Overview: Habitat suitability maps were produced for each community by projecting the posterior means of the fitted values predicted as probability of occurrence (between 0 and 1) by the best models. Data is from macrobenthos samples per community collected across in the Belgian part of the North Sea between 1994-2018.

🎯 Planning Objective: No specific planning objective.

<2>🗺️ Source Data: <2>Fishery Measures Report

📈 Report: The percentage of each feature type within this plan is calculated by finding the overlap of each feature type with the plan, summing its area, then dividing it by the total area of each feature type found within the planning area. If the plan includes multiple areas that overlap, the overlap is only counted once.
Biological Value Card: This report displays the biological value of benthic habitats within the Belgian part of the North Sea. Biological value ranges from 1 (very low) to 5 (very high) and can be used to inform the biological value of the area protected by your plan.
Biological Value Card - learn more:
ℹ️ Overview: The intrinsic biological value of an area is based on rarity, aggregation, fitness consequences, naturalness, and proportional importance. The biological value is independent from its socio-economics, and is a relative measure against other parts of the Belgian part of the North Sea. The biological value accounts for gravel beds, reefs, and suitable habitat of macrobenthos within the area.

🎯 Planning Objective: No specific planning objective.

<2>🗺️ Source Data: <2>Fishery Measures Report

📈 Report: The percentage of each feature type within this plan is calculated by finding the overlap of each feature type with the plan, summing its area, then dividing it by the total area of each feature type found within the planning area. If the plan includes multiple areas that overlap, the overlap is only counted once.
Gravel Beds Card: <0>Gravel beds are valuable habitats in the mainly sandy sediments of the southern North Sea. To assist in a recovery of their natural benthic communities, plans should consider the protection of gravel beds. </0>
Gravel Beds Card - learn more:
ℹ️ Overview: Unitil the early 20th century, gravel beds supported a rich fauna including sponges, bryozoa, hydrozoa, and flat oysters. Increased human pressure from bottom trawling and fishing have impacted the once-rich habitat. Gravel beds are classified as highly sensitive to degradation from human disturbance, as overturning or removal of stones often destroys fragile hard substrate fauna.

🎯 Planning Objective: No identified planning objectives for gravel beds.

<2>🗺️ Source Data: <2>Fishery Measures Report

📈 Report: The percentage of each feature type within this plan is calculated by finding the overlap of each feature type with the plan, summing its area, then dividing it by the total area of each feature type found within the planning area. If the plan includes multiple areas that overlap, the overlap is only counted once.
Lanice Card: <0>Lanice cochilega (sandmason bristleworm) aggregations form biogenic reefs, a valuable habitat in the Belgian part of the North Sea. Plans should consider the protection of Lanice conchilega biogenic aggregation areas.
Lanice Card - learn more:
<0>ℹ️ Overview: Lanice cochilega, the sand mason worm, form reef habitat in the Belgian part of the North Sea. These biogenic aggregations are hotspots for biodiversity, serving as nursery and shelter locations. While L. conchilega itself can recover quickly from fishing gear disruption, cohabitated species are more sensitive. The species has a low habitat specialization and a wide distribution, showing a patchy distribution pattern, but aggregates optimally in shallow, fine sands.<1>🎯 Planning Objective: No identified planning objectives for Lanice conchilega habitat.<2>🗺️ Source Data: <2>Fishery Measures Report

📈 Report: The percentage of each feature type within this plan is calculated by finding the overlap of each feature type with the plan, summing its area, then dividing it by the total area of each feature type found within the planning area. If the plan includes multiple areas that overlap, the overlap is only counted once.
SizeCard - introduction: national waters extend from the shoreline out to 200 nautical miles, known as the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). This report summarizes this plan's overlap with the EEZ, measuring progress towards achieving the 5%-10% EEZ protection target.
SizeCard - learn more:
ℹ️ Overview: This report summarizes the size and proportion of this plan within the Belgium EEZ on the North Sea.

🎯 Planning Objective: 5-10% of the Belgian EEZ, preferably in one large MPA.

<2>🗺️ Source Data: <2>Marine Regions - Maritime Boundaries

📈 Report: Percentage of EEZ protected is found by dividing the area of the plan by the area of the Belgium EEZ. If the plan includes multiple areas that overlap, the overlap is only counted once. Objective is considered achieved and given a checkmark when the % of the EEZ protected is greater than 5%.
